item.title: Amazon Faces New EU Antitrust Charges
item.description: The European Union allegations focus on how the online retailer uses vendor data to promote its own products, in a new salvo against U.S. technology companies.

item.title: Silicon Valley Gets Another President Skeptical of Big Tech
item.description: As a candidate, Joe Biden lambasted Facebook for what he considered failures to contain the spread of misinformation. His presidential election win puts him in a position to do something about it.

item.title: Apple Mac Line Gets New Life in Pandemic, In-House Chips
item.description: While excitement for Apple’s new iPhones has helped boost the company’s share price to record highs, a nearly 40-year-old workhorse with stagnating sales in recent years is notching impressive growth: the Mac.

item.title: China's Regulators Prepare to Roll Out New Antimonopoly Rules
item.description: China has released new draft antimonopoly rules for its online platforms, signaling an increased appetite by Beijing authorities to rein in dominant technology companies.

item.title: Spotify Buys Podcast-Tech Firm Megaphone
item.description: Spotify has agreed to acquire podcast advertising and publishing firm Megaphone in a deal that will help the streaming giant ramp up its ad business.

item.title: AI, Quantum R&D Funding to Remain a Priority Under Biden
item.description: The president-elect has proposed innovation funding of $300 billion over four years, in part to remain competitive with China.

item.title: In Biden, Detroit Gets a 'Car Guy' With Electric Vehicles on His Mind
item.description: A Joe Biden administration could mean both big changes and more certainty for the U.S. auto industry after turbulent but mostly lucrative years under President Donald Trump.

item.title: China's 'Uber for Trucks' Raising $1.7 Billion Ahead of IPO Next Year
item.description: Full Truck Alliance, a Chinese startup that provides an Uber-like service for the trucking industry, is being valued at $10 billion before the capital raise.

item.title: Nikola's Losses Widen as Executives Try to Regain Momentum
item.description: Electric-truck startup Nikola reported wider losses in the third-quarter, a tumultuous period in which company executives came under pressure to respond to questions about the legitimacy of its business.

item.title: iPhone 12 Mini Review: Fun Size, Not-So-Fun Battery Life
item.description: The iPhone 12 Mini does everything just as well as its larger iPhone 12 sibling—except one very important thing: lasting all day.

item.title: Apple Suspends New Business With Pegatron Over Labor Violations
item.description: Apple suspended new business with key supplier Pegatron after finding that the Taiwanese company violated the American smartphone maker’s rules related to student worker programs at its China facilities.

item.title: Targeted Ads Headed Soon to Network TV
item.description: Targeted advertising in which next-door neighbors could see different commercials during the same TV show has been television’s Holy Grail, but it is expected to become a reality next year.

item.title: 5G's Early Business Adopters Explore New Generation of Wireless Applications
item.description: Business users in areas such as auto manufacturing are driving most of the applications, at least for now.

item.title: GM Plans to Hire 3,000 New Workers to Deepen Tech Expertise
item.description: GM is looking to bolster its engineering and software-development ranks by recruiting new employees, the latest auto maker to bulk up on tech talent as competition with Silicon Valley intensifies for the future automobile.

item.title: Zoom to Get Closer Scrutiny Under FTC Settlement
item.description: The federal agency had alleged that Zoom for at least the past four years promised users a level of data encryption it didn’t provide.

item.title: How Eli Lilly Developed Covid-19 Drug in Pandemic's Long Shadow
item.description: Pharma companies seeking vaccines and treatments have had to adapt to an unusual impediment—having to carry out their work on the disease while it’s all around them. That’s led to some peculiar workarounds and continued nervousness.

item.title: SoftBank Comeback Stays on Track With $6 Billion Profit
item.description: Technology investor SoftBank Group logged a profit of more than $6 billion in the July-September quarter, driven by rising share prices for some of its portfolio companies.

item.title: This College Degree Is Brought to You by Amazon
item.description: As university budgets are squeezed and student debt loads rise, an era of close-knit relationships between companies and universities is getting under way.

item.title: Intel's Success Came With Making Its Own Chips. Until Now.
item.description: The Silicon Valley pioneer long held it had to build its flagship chips, the brains of computers, in its own factories. Then it hit the wall with a new generation and is considering outsourcing—a milestone in the story of America’s losing its manufacturing primacy.

item.title: Kevin Mayer, Ex-TikTok CEO, Joins Investment Firm Founded By Billionaire Len Blavatnik
item.description: Access Industries said Mr. Mayer will focus on its media-related businesses and identify new potential opportunities for the firm.

item.title: Private 5G Networks Are Bringing Bandwidth Where Carriers Aren't
item.description: Impatient for faster connectivity for everything from smart factories to rural broadband, companies are rolling out their own networks.

item.title: U.S. vs. China in 5G: The Battle Isn't Even Close
item.description: China is leading the way in the size and consistency of its 5G network.

item.title: Covid-19 Vaccine Safety Efforts to Feature App Tracking
item.description: Health officials and drugmakers plan to roll out extra tools to detect whether coronavirus vaccines cause any serious side effects once the shots are cleared for widespread use, aiming to fill gaps in existing safeguards given the expected speed and scope of the rollout.
